eccoLocation.resp: This file prepared by Ashley Necciai

sourceDesc.p: Search terms extracted from the following text(s): VariousThe fugitive miscellany. Being a collection of such fugitive pieces, in prose and verse, as are not in any other collection. With many pieces never before published. 2London1774The hit for poe was the word poem, but when you search inside the work for Otaheite you get a poem that was written as though it were from Oberea to Banks. It might be worth looking at because it references actual events from the voyage logs.Omiah's farewell; inscribed to the ladies of London.printed for G. Kearsly, in Fleet-Street, MDCCLXXVI.London1776Worth keeping because it is an example of a poem that was written using the voyage accounts rather than just a summary.

bibl.title: An epistle from Mr. Banks, voyager, monster-hunter, and amoroso, to Oberea, Queen of Otaheite. Transfused by A. B. C. Esq. ... Enriched with the finest passages of the Queen's letter to Mr. Banks.
bibl.note: Second edition. Another poem like the fugitive miscellany and Omiah's farewell.

bibl.author: Scott, Major (John)
bibl.title: An epistle from Oberea, Queen of Otaheite, to Joseph Banks, Esq. Translated by T. Q. Z. Esq. Professor of the Otaheite language in Dublin, and of all the Languages of the undiscovered Islands in the South Sea; and enriched with historical and explanatory notes.
bibl.note: Another poem that the author used the voyage logs to write.

bibl.author: Courtenay, John
bibl.title: An epistle (moral and philosophical) from an officer at Otaheite. To Lady Gr*s**n*r. With notes, critical and historical. By the author of The rape of Pomona.
bibl.note: Another poem, this time from the point of view of an officer at Otaheite. References the voyage logs in the footnotes.

item.term: bread-tree OR bread tree OR breadtree

bibl.author: Preston, William
bibl.title: The poetical works of William Preston, Esq. in two volumes. ...
bibl.note: Another poem, this time from a lady from Britain to Omiah.
